Does a shooter mean you’re writing PID for a pivot that controls the orientation or that controls the shooter wheel?
Either way, these resources can help and if you have more specific questions you can ask them again in this thread:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

PID Control in WPILib

WPILib supports PID control of mechanisms through the PIDController class ( Java, C++, Python). This class handles the feedback loop calculation for the user, as well as offering methods for return...

You’ll also likely want to use feedforward control in conjunction with your feedback (PID) control:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Feedforward Control in WPILib

You may have used feedback control (such as PID) for reference tracking (making a system’s output follow a desired reference signal). While this is effective, it’s a reactionary measure; the system...

Finally, which motors are you using (NEO + SPARK MAX, NEO Vortex + SPARK Flex, Falcon 500 w/ TalonFX, Kraken X60/X44 w/ TalonFX, or something else)?

Here is REV’s example code for a velocity control loop.

Note how tiny the proportional gain (kP) is in this example code. NEO + SparkMAX is not a good combination for velocity control of many shooters. If your shooter has a lot of mass in either the shooter wheels or from a flywheel on the shooter axle, you might be able to get decent velocity control. If your shooter does not have a lot of rotating mass, the noisy velocity signal from the NEO internal encoder is going to make it difficult to get stable velocity control with good setpoint tracking. If you don’t have the option to do shooter velocity control with a Kraken or Falcon, you might be able to get better velocity performance if you use a good external encoder for velocity feedback rather than using the NEO internal encoder.

One more comment…

In many cases, you don’t need feedback control for shooter velocity. If the time between shots is sufficient for open-loop (constant voltage) shooter velocity to recover from the load of a shot, you may be able to get very repeatable shooter performance without feedback. If you are shooting multiple objects in very close succession, good feedback can help make all shots very similar to the first. Of course, in that kind of situation, a flywheel to increase the rotational inertia of the shooter is also very helpful and that inertia makes feedback velocity control with a NEO/SparkMAX more feasible.
